properties.name: 1,031 Trees in Cass Lake, Minnesota (planted in 1997)
properties.description: Posted by Cecilkleakins Cass Lake, MinnesotaIn Cass Lake, a reservation town in Northern Minnesota, 1,031 seedlings were planted representing approximately one tree per resident. The planting itself took place over a one-week period in late May 1997. Residents themselves determined where the trees were sited -- on their own property as well as on public land -- and were actively involved in the planting as well. In conjunction with the 1997 show "Joseph Beuys Multiples" at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. Project was coordinated by independent curator Todd Bockley with support from the Visual Arts Department, as well as the Education Department\'s Teen Programs and Community Programs. More Info: http://www.walkerart.org/archive/9/A343D1DFBAD672436161.htm

properties.name: A Slow, Sad Decline
properties.description: Posted by PaloaltohistoryEdgewood Plaza, designed by for Joseph Eichler was once a jewel of a small shopping center, opening 1958 in his original California style. When it opened, it began with a Lucky\'s Supermarket as its anchor store surrounded by a collection of small shops. The Edgewood mall also housed Joseph Eichler\'s headquarters and stands today as his only commercial shopping center. In recent years the center has had African City Alive, Albertson\'s supermarket, Country Side Delicatessen, Century Liquors, Moon\'s One Hour Cleaners, a golf store, House of Wigs, a hair salon, a shoe repair store, Formico\'s Pizza, Brother\'s Farm Fresh Produce,a Shell Gas Station and the Maharishi Vedic School. In the past 50 years, however, only minor improvements have been made and the mall has become dilapitated. Some have estimated that sales at the center have dropped as much as 60 percent in the last decade. The Albertson’s which has operated there for many years has had a mediocre reputation at best. On one Internet bulletin board, a person called it "the worst major grocery store" he or she had ever visited. As Palo Alto Councilman Larry Klein told the Daily News, "in emergencies we shopped there," said Councilman Larry Klein, who lives in the area. "Our shopping was limited to things like milk and orange juice and batteries. It was in awful shape."

properties.name: Cuisine of Thailand - Little Orchids

properties.name: Dirty Blossom For The Broken Ground
properties.description: Posted by Baostar    I remember the rainy days in Tokyo when we first met - though Japan is quite beautiful in the springtime, especially when the sakuras bloom and blanket the ground like snow. I was wandering around Ueno Park, leaving the crowd of people and Hanami parties behind, when you tapped my shoulder and asked me to take a photo of you standing in front of a temple, on top of the hill. You spoke charmingly with a British accent, Chinese-born and living in London. You were amazingly backpacking through Japan on your own for a month. We shared stories of our trips, and then you showed a map of your adventure plans. We swapped emails and addresses. We took pictures of ourselves. When I got back home I received a postcard from you in Nagoya - and later, stories of a dodgy hotel in Osaka, the peril of riding bikes in Kyoto, among other life\'s off-kilter experiences. I sent winded emails of little things about me, hoping you\'ll get in touch with me when you get home, but somehow you didn\'t. Now it\'s springtime again and I\'m thinking of going to London. I want to give you a call when I do make it to the swanky shopping district of London - and hopefully, you\'ll remember me, still, after the long-distance spell. But my nerves are weak now and "all the umbrellas in London couldn\'t stop this rain."

properties.name: The first year of my life
properties.description: Posted by Mydogischelseaholland park, London, EnglandI don\'t remember a thing about London, but I was born there. Learned to walk there, too, in a pick-your-own-strawberry patch. There\'s a picture of that first step somewhere. My father once argued that he took the picture; I proved him wrong when it turned out he was in it, too.

properties.name: the city gives out tickets on a stinkie street they never clean
properties.description: Posted by Ludmillahow could i tell it was a hydrant - i thought it was a bush. it doesn\'t work, all its fitting are broken off and there is a bush growing out of it. people sleep in their cars and motor homes on this block and stay there for weeks at a time. i found a poor dead smelly dog under a pile of cardboard right on this corner. there is so much poop and trash and broken glass on this block that i wonder how the city can dare fine me 00 for having parked here.
